Error while unpacking a well formed pcap file
items.body:
Hello,
I created a simple program to read a pcap file: 
```python
    import dpkt
    import sys
    if __name__ == "__main__":
         FILE = sys.argv[1] 
         arq = open(FILE, 'rb')
         pcap = dpkt.pcap.Reader(arq)
         for ts, data in pcap:
            eth = dpkt.ethernet.Ethernet(data)
            print(eth)
```
The pcap file that I was trying to read is the following: https://mcfp.felk.cvut.cz/publicDatasets/CTU-Normal-20/2017-04-30_win-normal.pcap

And here is the traceback of the error:

Traceback (most recent call last):

dpkt.dpkt.NeedData


I've tried to modify the unpack function on line 168 of dpkt.py with this code, but it did not work:
```python

items.title: IEEE 802.1Q double tagging (QinQ) with miscellaneous data parsing problem
items.body:
In ethernet module in case of vlan double tagging with a following unknown data part (isinstance(self.data, bytes)==True) the first 4 bytes of the data are parsed as an additional vlan tag.

This happens because when self.data is not of a particular known type, _unpack_data is being called once more. Since the next_type variable is local and is given the value of the uppermost tag (which would be vlan) the code enters an additional iteration of the loop that appends vlan_tags and bites into the first 4 bytes of the data.

items.title: snaplen is hard-coded to 1500 bytes
items.body:
when working with other snapshot lengths (1514 in my case), the NETRESEC trimpcap.py script, which uses dpkt, truncates each packet to 1500 bytes.  Initial review of the dpkt source shows this value is hard-coded:
* https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/blob/0aa3a6e9c7cce3a54b8c10691f3271f6f0ca95a5/dpkt/pcap.py#L181

Instead of this value, snapshot length should be taken from source file and all bytes per packet should be retained.

items.title: Regression in v1.9.2 serializing 802.1q VLAN tagged ARP Requests
items.body:
```
from binascii import hexlify
from dpkt.ethernet import *
from dpkt.arp import *

e = Ethernet()
v = VLANtag8021Q()
v.pri = 0
v.cfi = 0
v.id = 1
e.vlan_tags = [v]
e.dst=b'\xff' * 6
e.src=b'foobar',
e.type=ETH_TYPE_ARP,
a = ARP()
a.sha = b'foobar'
a.spa = bytes((10,10,10,10))
a.tha = b''
a.tpa = bytes((10,10,10,5))
e.data = a
print(v.type, e.type)
print(hexlify(bytes(e)).decode("ASCII"))
print(v.type, e.type)
```

Output with dpkt 1.9.2:
`2048 (2054,)`
`ffffffffffff666f6f62617281000001`**`0800`**`0001080006040001666f6f6261720a0a0a0a0000000000000a0a0a05`
`2048 (2054,)`
the highlighted part is (incorrect) `ETH_TYPE_IP`

Output with dpkt 1.9.1
`2048 (2054,)`
`ffffffffffff666f6f62617281000001`**`0806`**`0001080006040001666f6f6261720a0a0a0a0000000000000a0a0a05`
`(2054,) (2054,)`
the highlighted part is (correct) `ETH_TYPE_ARP`.

Changing the order of the assignments to `e`'s properties (e.g. `vlan_tags` after `type` and/or `payload`) does not help. The only way I was able to get the correct/desired output was by explicitly setting `v.type = ETH_TYPE_ARP`.

I strongly suspect the change in behavior was caused by https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/commit/63c318f67a1ed1c48c79fbff90759ea0bf71a75d

items.title: Netbios name encoding bug
items.body:
When encoding names in netbios packets I encounter the following problem:
```
Python 3.7.4 (default, Jul  9 2019, 18:13:23)
[Clang 10.0.1 (clang-1001.0.46.4)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import dpkt
>>> payload = bytes.fromhex(
...     '20434b4141414141414141414141414141'
...     '4141414141414141414141414141414100')
>>> decoded_payload = dpkt.netbios.decode_name(payload)
>>> print(decoded_payload)
b' CKAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA\x00'
>>> encoded_payload = dpkt.netbios.encode_name(decoded_payload)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/dpkt/netbios.py", line 16, in encode_name
    c = ord(c)
TypeError: ord() expected string of length 1, but int found
>>>
```
 
It seems like dpkt has a bug in encode_name and decode_name where python2 is not correctly converted to python3. This is my proposed fix:

```
import struct
import dpkt
import binascii


def encode_name(decoded_name):
    """Return the NetBIOS first-level encoded name."""
    encoded_name = bytearray()
    for c in decoded_name:
        encoded_name.append((c >> 4) + 0x41)
        encoded_name.append((c & 0xf) + 0x41)
    return encoded_name


def decode_name(encoded_name):
    """Return the NetBIOS first-level decoded nbname."""
    decoded_name = bytearray()
    for i in range(0, len(encoded_name), 2):
        decoded_name.append(
            ((encoded_name[i] - 0x41) << 4) |
            ((encoded_name[i + 1] - 0x41) & 0xf))
    return decoded_name[:decoded_name.index(b'\x00')+1]


payload = bytes.fromhex(
    '20434b4141414141414141414141414141'
    '4141414141414141414141414141414100')
print(payload)
decoded_payload = encode_name(payload)
print(decoded_payload)
encoded_payload = decode_name(decoded_payload)
print(payload, encoded_payload)
print(payload == encoded_payload)
print('Great success!!!')
```
I have no idea why there is a character limit of 16 chars, I have removed them in my fix, if this is protocol related they have to be reinserted.

items.title: hasattribute usage vs getattribute or try/ except
items.body:
In https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/blob/8c15c6ca21461996eefe80274f9ba7e7548a796f/dpkt/__init__.py#L83-L85
it would probably be better to implement with getattribute or try/ except. If the case `hasattr(mod, '_mod_init')` is mostly true and only sometimes false, this could even yield better performance. See discussion [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/903130/hasattr-vs-try-except-block-to-deal-with-non-existent-attributes).

items.title: Mostly zero ethernet frame throws exception
items.body:
The attached pcap has a single packet that causes a `NeedData` exception in dpkt 1.9.2.

[capture.zip](https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/files/2747090/capture.zip)

The frame looks like:

```
00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 | 16
00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 | 32
00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 | 48
00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 08 89 12 04 | 64
```

Example:

```python
for timestamp, buf in dpkt.pcap.Reader(f):
    eth = dpkt.ethernet.Ethernet(buf)
    print(eth)

```

Since the `ethertype` field is 0, it is being treated as logical link control, and throwing an exception:

```python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
error                                     Traceback (most recent call last)
c:\workspace\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
     88             try:
---> 89                 self.unpack(args[0])
     90             except struct.error:

c:\workspace\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt\llc.py in unpack(self, buf)
     35
---> 36         dpkt.Packet.unpack(self, buf)
     37         if self.is_snap:

c:\workspace\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt.py in unpack(self, buf)
    170         for k, v in compat_izip(self.__hdr_fields__,
--> 171                                 struct.unpack(self.__hdr_fmt__, buf[:self.__hdr_len__])):
    172             setattr(self, k, v)

error: unpack requires a buffer of 3 bytes

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

NeedData                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-a483b3f3f387> in <module>
      1 for timestamp, buf in dpkt.pcap.Reader(f):
----> 2     eth = dpkt.ethernet.Ethernet(buf)
      3     print(eth)
      4

c:\workspace\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt\ethernet.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
     77
     78     def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
---> 79         dpkt.Packet.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
     80         # if data was given in kwargs, try to unpack it
     81         if self.data:

c:\workspace\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
     87         if args:
     88             try:
---> 89                 self.unpack(args[0])
     90             except struct.error:
     91                 if len(args[0]) < self.__hdr_len__:

c:\workspace\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt\ethernet.py in unpack(self, buf)
    166                         self.fcs = struct.unpack('>I', self.data[-4:])[0]
    167                         self.trailer = self.data[eth_len:-4]
--> 168             self.data = self.llc = llc.LLC(self.data[:eth_len])
    169
    170     def pack_hdr(self):

c:\workspace\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt\dpkt.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
     90             except struct.error:
     91                 if len(args[0]) < self.__hdr_len__:
---> 92                     raise NeedData
     93                 raise UnpackError('invalid %s: %r' %
     94                                   (self.__class__.__name__, args[0]))

NeedData:
```

Anyone ever seen this? Ideas on what to do about this ethernet frame? Should we check for the ethertype 0 case in Ethernet.unpack instead of letting it fall through the if to the else case that interprets as logic link control?

Right now I am just checking for zero ethertype and throwing away:

```python
for timestamp, buf in dpkt.pcap.Reader(f):
    if len(buf) > 14 and buf[12:14] == b'\x00\x00':
        continue
    eth = dpkt.ethernet.Ethernet(buf)
```

Should we check for this case in Ethernet.upack()?

items.title: MPLS decoding to support PW ECW
items.body:
The following input is Eth - MPLS - MPLS - ECW - Eth - ARP
```
buf = (
    b'\xcc\x00\x0d\x5c\x00\x10\xcc\x01\x0d\x5c\x00\x10\x88\x47\x00\x01\x30\xfe\x00\x01\x01\xff'
    b'\x00\x00\x00\x00\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\x00\x50\x79\x66\x68\x00\x08\x06\x00\x01\x08\x00'
    b'\x06\x04\x00\x01\x00\x50\x79\x66\x68\x00\xc0\xa8\x00\x0a\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\xc0\xa8'
    b'\x00\x14\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00'
    b'\x00\x00'
)
```

Currently decodes to:
```
Ethernet(
    dst='\xcc\x00\r\\\x00\x10', 
    src='\xcc\x01\r\\\x00\x10', 
    labels=[(19, 0, 254), (16, 0, 255)], 
    mpls_labels=[
        MPLSlabel(s=0, exp=0, val=19, ttl=254), 
        MPLSlabel(s=1, exp=0, val=16, ttl=255)
    ], 
    data='\x00\x00\x00\x00\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\x00Pyfh....
```

We need to support Pseudo-wire Ethernet Control Word (ECW) to decode to smth like this instead:
```
Ethernet(
    dst='\xcc\x00\r\\\x00\x10', 
    src='\xcc\x01\r\\\x00\x10', 
    labels=[(19, 0, 254), (16, 0, 255)], 
    mpls_labels=[
        MPLSlabel(s=0, exp=0, val=19, ttl=254), 
        MPLSlabel(s=1, exp=0, val=16, ttl=255)
    ], 
    data=ECW(
        seq=0,
        data=Ethernet(
            dst='\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff\xff', 
            src='\x00Pyfh\x00', type=2054, 
            data=ARP(sha='\x00Pyfh\x00', ...
``` 

For reference this is how Wireshark does it https://www.wireshark.org/lists/wireshark-bugs/201406/msg00823.html

items.title: dpkt.http.py L125: AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'decode'
items.body:
https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/blob/master/dpkt/http.py#L125
TL;DR;
`self.body` can be None, where `__str__` does not account for this possibility.

Code that breaks:

    sip = methodstatus = None
    body = body.decode('utf-8', 'replace').encode('utf-8')
    try:
        sip = dpkt.sip.Request(body)
        requestresponse = 'request'
        methodstatus = sip.method
    except (KeyError, dpkt.dpkt.UnpackError, ValueError):
        try:
            sip = dpkt.sip.Response(body)
            requestresponse = 'response'
            sip.method = sip.headers['cseq'].partition(' ')[2]
            methodstatus = sip.status + ' (' + sip.reason + ')'
        except (KeyError, dpkt.dpkt.UnpackError, ValueError):
            # Neither a valid sip request or response, skip the rest.
            continue

    if sip and sip.headers.get('call-id') not in pcaps['callids']:
        pcaps['callids'].append(sip.headers.get('call-id'))

This raises an AttributeError:

      File "/home/uittenbroek/projects/xx/xx/base/misc/debug/utils.py", line 79, in parsecall
        if sip and sip.headers.get('call-id') not in pcaps['callids']:
      File "/home/uittenbroek/.virtualenvs/xx/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dpkt/http.py", line 122, in __len__
        return len(str(self))
      File "/home/uittenbroek/.virtualenvs/xx/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dpkt/http.py", line 239, in __str__
        self.reason) + Message.__str__(self)
      File "/home/uittenbroek/.virtualenvs/xx/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/dpkt/http.py", line 127, in __str__
        return '%s\r\n%s' % (self.pack_hdr(), self.body.decode("utf8", "ignore"))
    AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'decode'

Due to the [Response.unpack](https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/blob/master/dpkt/http.py#L232) looking at the self.status, for this specific item this status  '100'.
Causing `is_body_allowed` to be False, resulting in [body not being set.](https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/blob/master/dpkt/http.py#L113)

But the `__str__` function always expects body to be a string type with a decode function.

items.title: Inefficient packet writing
items.body:
Each packet write checks the system endianness, and constructs an LE/PktHdr, to allow the packet to be written. 

I am not aware of conditions under which system endianness could change between packet writes, so this testing should be moved to the Writer initialization instead.

items.title: We're not doing 802.1q and 802.1ad correctly in ethernet.py
items.body:
Currently in ethernet.py if a packet has an 802.1q header we replace the outer ethertype with the one from the 802.1q header. This happens at ethernet.py line 89. This should not happen.

Also, 802.1ad (commonly called QinQ, or Virtual Metro Area Networks(VMAN)) is not done by stacking 0x8100 ethertypes. Cisco recommends 0x9100 or 0x9200 in its QinQ docs[1]. I think it is rather weak on Cisco's part that they recommend this, as they should be adhering to 802.1ad, but whatever. The 802.1ad standard says to use 0x88a8.[2] It can theoretically be anything, which is of course a problem, but I think we can do better. 

The code in ethernet.py lines 85-93 takes none of this into account and instead assumes a stacking of ethertypes 0x8100, which I doubt anyone is actually doing. Because it would mean any intermediate switch wouldn't know if a frame is single or double tagged.

I'm fine developing the code for all this, but before I propose any PR I want to get the opinion of the devs on this. Because I suspect there is a reason for the current behavior.

I'm assuming for now that dpkt will never support 802.1ah, which would be a serious pain. Luckily I think it's mostly been obviated by Nortel's death and the rise of VPLS.

[1] https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/10000/10008/feature/guides/qinq.html
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_802.1ad

items.title: Python3 OSPF default auth field packet packing error
items.body:
There is a bug in the current version of dpkt on Python3. If the auth header field is omitted when initiating an OSPF packet, an exception is raised. Here is a quick test and stack-trace using the Python3 interpreter.

```Python 3.5.2 (default, Nov 17 2016, 17:05:23) 
[GCC 5.4.0 20160609] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from dpkt.ospf import OSPF
>>> packet = OSPF(v=1,type=1,area=0,len=0,router=0,data=b'')
>>> packet.__bytes__()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/dpkt/dpkt.py", line 150, in pack_hdr
    *[getattr(self, k) for k in self.__hdr_fields__])
struct.error: argument for 's' must be a bytes object

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/dpkt/dpkt.py", line 160, in pack_hdr
    return struct.pack(self.__hdr_fmt__, *vals)
struct.error: argument for 's' must be a bytes object

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/dpkt/ospf.py", line 36, in __bytes__
    self.sum = dpkt.in_cksum(dpkt.Packet.__bytes__(self))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/dpkt/dpkt.py", line 144, in __bytes__
    return self.pack_hdr() + bytes(self.data)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/dpkt/dpkt.py", line 162, in pack_hdr
    raise PackError(str(e))
dpkt.dpkt.PackError: argument for 's' must be a bytes object
```

The problem is due to the auth field having an invalid value set as its default `''`. This should be `b''` in python 3 as strings are now stored in Unicode. Can also fix this by using the encode method to translate the string to bytes before the packet processing occurs, but this may be more messy.

Here is a link to the file and line in question. [dpkt/ospf.py line 31](https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/blob/master/dpkt/ospf.py#L31)

If we set the auth field value to `b''` we get the expected output.

```Python 3.5.2 (default, Nov 17 2016, 17:05:23) 
[GCC 5.4.0 20160609] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from dpkt.ospf import OSPF
>>> packet = OSPF(v=1,type=1,area=0,len=0,router=0,auth=b'',data=b'')
>>> packet.__bytes__()
b'\x01\x01\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\xfe\xfe\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00\x00'
```

items.title: Recursion error when creating a string from an ICMP packet.
items.body:
I'm using the following code to build an ICMP packet.
```
def build_icmp_echo(id=0, seq=0, data=''):
    echo = dpkt.icmp.ICMP.Echo()
    echo.id = id
    echo.seq = seq
    echo.data = data

    icmp = dpkt.icmp.ICMP()
    icmp.type = dpkt.icmp.ICMP_ECHO
    icmp.data = str(data)

    return icmp
```
When I call str() on the ICMP object I get the following stack trace:
```
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dpkt/dpkt.py", line 141, in __str__
    return str(self.__bytes__())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dpkt/icmp.py", line 130, in __bytes__
    self.sum = dpkt.in_cksum(dpkt.Packet.__str__(self))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dpkt/dpkt.py", line 141, in __str__
    return str(self.__bytes__())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dpkt/icmp.py", line 130, in __bytes__
    self.sum = dpkt.in_cksum(dpkt.Packet.__str__(self))
```

The stack trace continues like this until a max recursion depth error is reached. The `ICMP.__bytes__()` method is calling the `dpkt.Packet.__str__()` method, which calls the `ICMP.__bytes__()` method. This only affects 1.9.0, so I assume it is an artifact of adding the Python 3 support. I am running my code in Python 2.7.

items.title: Handle non-ascii HTTP Headers
items.body:
From @scott-hand
RFC 7230 advice: "In practice, most HTTP header field values use only a subset of the US-ASCII charset [USASCII]. Newly defined header fields SHOULD limit their field values to US-ASCII octets. A recipient SHOULD treat other octets in field content (obs-text) as opaque data."

Right now (after https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/pull/336 is merged) non-ascii characters in the header will be silently dropped.

items.title: "in_cksum_add" should use "compat_ord" for Python3 Compatibility
items.body:
`in_cksum_add` in `dpkt.py` raises TypeError when running with Python3.

```shell-session
In [46]: c = b'\x01\x02\x03\x04\x05\x06\x07\x08\n'
In [47]: dpkt.dpkt.in_cksum_add(0, c)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-47-ab52915f6273> in <module>()
----> 1 dpkt.dpkt.in_cksum_add(0, c)

/Users/Yoshiyuki/.pyenv/versions/3.5.2/lib/python3.5/site-packages/dpkt-1.9.0-py3.5.egg/dpkt/dpkt.py in in_cksum_add(s, buf)
    195     a = array.array('H', buf[:cnt])
    196     if cnt != n:
--> 197         a.append(struct.unpack('H', buf[-1] + '\x00')[0])
    198     return s + sum(a)
    199

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'int' and 'str'
```

This is due to the implementation of bytes object in Python3, which actually is the array of integers.  
In this line,
`      a.append(struct.unpack('H', buf[-1] + '\x00')[0])`
`buf[-1]` in Python2 returns byte(=string) object like '\n', but that of Python3 returns '10'.

This can easily be fixed by using `compat_ord` instead of `struct.unpack`, so I'll open PR shortly.

items.title: ICMP payload inside IP packets isn't parsed under Python2
items.body:
Current code in dpkt git (1.9.0) cannot parse ICMP packets (and some other protocols) when run under Python2, but works fine under Python3.

My git HEAD is 65b3d9716b80d17e5bffb66f57230ddeee384f75

## Reproducer

    import dpkt
    with open("ip_frag_source.pcap", 'rb') as f:
        pcap = dpkt.pcap.Reader(f)
        for ts, buf in pcap:
            eth = dpkt.ethernet.Ethernet(buf)
            ip = eth.data
            print(type(ip.data))

Note: The PCAP file ``ip_frag_source.pcap`` can be downloaded from http://chrissanders.org/packet-captures/

## Outputs

### Python 2

    $ python2.7 reproducer.py
    <type 'str'>
    ....

### Python 3

    $ python3.5 reproducer.py
    <class 'dpkt.icmp.ICMP'>
    ....

## Debugging

I added raise statement into ``__load_protos`` function in ``ip.py`` to see the exception:

    try:
        mod = __import__(name, g, level=1)
        IP.set_proto(v, getattr(mod, name.upper()))
    except (ImportError, AttributeError) as err:
        if name == "icmp":  # XXX Debug
            raise           # XXX Debug
        continue

and result is:

    $ python2.7 ./reproducer.py 
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "./reproducer.py", line 3, in <module>
        import dpkt
      File "/home/tojaj/git/dpkt/dpkt/__init__.py", line 33, in <module>
        from . import icmp
      File "/home/tojaj/git/dpkt/dpkt/icmp.py", line 8, in <module>
        from . import ip
      File "/home/tojaj/git/dpkt/dpkt/ip.py", line 362, in <module>
        __load_protos()
      File "/home/tojaj/git/dpkt/dpkt/ip.py", line 354, in __load_protos
        IP.set_proto(v, getattr(mod, name.upper()))
    AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'ICMP'


## Comparison of supported payloads under Python2 and Python3

### Code

    import dpkt
    from pprint import pprint
    pprint(dpkt.ip.IP._protosw)

### Python2

    $ python2.7 ./reproducer.py 
    {0: <class 'dpkt.ip.IP'>,
     2: <class 'dpkt.igmp.IGMP'>,
     4: <class 'dpkt.ip.IP'>,
     6: <class 'dpkt.tcp.TCP'>,
     17: <class 'dpkt.udp.UDP'>,
     41: <class 'dpkt.ip6.IP6'>,
     50: <class 'dpkt.esp.ESP'>,
     51: <class 'dpkt.ah.AH'>,
     89: <class 'dpkt.ospf.OSPF'>,
     103: <class 'dpkt.pim.PIM'>,
     112: <class 'dpkt.vrrp.VRRP'>,
     118: <class 'dpkt.stp.STP'>,
     132: <class 'dpkt.sctp.SCTP'>}

### Python3

    $ python3.5 ./reproducer.py 
    {0: <class 'dpkt.ip.IP'>,
     1: <class 'dpkt.icmp.ICMP'>,
     2: <class 'dpkt.igmp.IGMP'>,
     4: <class 'dpkt.ip.IP'>,
     6: <class 'dpkt.tcp.TCP'>,
     17: <class 'dpkt.udp.UDP'>,
     41: <class 'dpkt.ip6.IP6'>,
     47: <class 'dpkt.gre.GRE'>,
     50: <class 'dpkt.esp.ESP'>,
     51: <class 'dpkt.ah.AH'>,
     58: <class 'dpkt.icmp6.ICMP6'>,
     89: <class 'dpkt.ospf.OSPF'>,
     103: <class 'dpkt.pim.PIM'>,
     112: <class 'dpkt.vrrp.VRRP'>,
     118: <class 'dpkt.stp.STP'>,
     132: <class 'dpkt.sctp.SCTP'>}

As you can see ``ICMP``, ``GRE`` and ``ICMP6`` protocols are missing from ``dpkt.ip.IP._protosw`` dict under Python2 in comparison to Python3.

items.title: Investigate for Memory Leaks
items.body:
While reading [this](https://reproducingnetworkresearch.wordpress.com/2016/05/30/cs244-16-an-accurate-sampling-scheme-for-detecting-syn-flooding-attacks-and-portscans/) article, I noticed that the author talks about a memory leak in dpkt. It seems that they were trying to reproduce [this](http://mkorczynski.com/An%20Accurate%20Sampling%20Scheme%20for%20Detecting%20SYN.pdf) paper's results.

> Unfortunately, after writing most of our code and testing on smaller datasets, we ran it on a larger file and discovered a memory leak in the library. This made it tricky to run our code on very large pcap files, and ended up capping the max number of packets we could process  and analyze to 27 million (on a machine running with 32 GB of RAM). 

They go on to say the following in the feedback section of the paper:

> The main issue was with the memory leak in dpkt. We were able to get around it by just running our code on machines with a lot of memory (Felipe’s laptop has 16GB of RAM, and Keziah spun up an AWS instance with 32 GB of RAM and we stopped having problems). However, if you want to run locally on machines with less memory, I would avoid this library.

Specifically about this issue - I dont yet know where/what leak they found, but I am going to ping them about it. Hopefully we can reproduce & fix this, iff this is a problem with dpkt.

It is easier to blame this on python's internal memory allocator, which does not release memory back to the OS, but lets see. Maybe we can add some code patterns to the examples which could be used as a workaround (for not just dpkt, but for python performance/memory problems in general).  

Update: 
- The dataset is available [here](http://www.caida.org/data/passive/ddos-20070804_dataset.xml)
- The code used in the test is available [here](https://github.com/felipems/cs244_final_project)

items.title: any plan to support more BGP Address family like VPNv4/v6?
dpkt.http needs to check for '\r\n', since we may have fragmented requests
items.body:
Sometimes HTTP requests are too large to fit in one TCP segment, which means on parsing pcap TCP segments it is possible to pass an incomplete header to the dpkt.http decoder. Fixed with the following patch in http.py:

[patch.txt](https://github.com/kbandla/dpkt/files/230908/patch.txt)

items.title: pcap.py: DLT_RAW constant value
items.body: Why DLT_RAW is defined to be 14 or 12? In my experience of running tcpdump on tun-interface, it produced pcap files containing just IPv4 packets (i.e. no Ethernet or other kind of encapsulation) with datalink type of 101 (0x65), which was consistent with tcpdump.org definition of DLT_RAW (http://www.tcpdump.org/linktypes.html)

items.title: Stop pypcap from capturing and writing network traffic to a file
items.body:
I'm capturing network traffic with pypcap and writing it to a file with dpkt. Problem is I can't delete the file as I get an error saying it's still in use by another process. 

```
seconds = 15
starttime = datetime.datetime.now()

pc = pcap.pcap()
file = open('file.pcap', 'wb')
pcapfile = dpkt.pcap.Writer(file)

for timestamp, packet in pc:
    currenttime = datetime.datetime.now()
    timedelta = currenttime - starttime
    if timedelta.seconds > seconds:
        break

    pcapfile.writepkt(packet,timestamp)
pcapfile.close()
file.close()

time.sleep(10)

os.remove(file.pcap) = file in use by another process error
```

I'm currently overwriting the pcap file the next time I capture traffic. Doing this overwrites the file data most of the time, but occasionally it doesn't work and I end up with a large pcap file encompassing two sets of network capture data.  

How do you close the pcapy/dpkt process handle?

Also does anyone know a better way to stop pcapy capturing traffic after 15 seconds?

Landscape.io seems to be down for like a week now (not a good sign), so probably we'll switch our code quality metrics to Scrutinizer (https://scrutinizer-ci.com). 

See this for example of how to change:
https://github.com/SuperCowPowers/chains/commit/cb0c3b04ee18033ff37c44276df3d56324fd71eb

items.title: Should we drop Python 2.5 and older Python support in dpkt 2.0?
items.body:
Hi there,

Recently I was working on migrating `dpkt` to Python 3, which is an important feature of dpkt 2.0. I discussed with @kbandla early today about dropping the support for Python 2.5 and older versions in our new release. Because we suppose there are not so many users still run our packet on those old Python machines, also it will make it easier for our migration job. For instance, in Python 2 iterators have a `.next()` method we use to get the next value from the iterator. For example,

``` python
>>> i = iter(range(5))
>>> i.next()
0
>>> i.next()
1
```

This special method has in Python 3 been renamed to `.__next__()` to be consistent with the naming of special attributes elswhere in Python. However, we should generally not call it directly, but instead use the builtin is `next()` function. _However, this function is only available from Python 2.6._

There are also some similar issues for the migration to Python 3. Thus what's your opinion? Should we just drop the support for old Python versions (<= 2.5)?

Thanks,
Hao

items.title: Provide both Python 2 and 3 support for metaclass.
items.body:
This is a problem I met when migrating the `dpkt` to Python 3.

We use metaclass in `dpkt.py` module. Unfortunately the syntax of metaclass in Python 2 and 3 are not the same. 

_Python 2_

``` python
class Packet(object):
    __metaclass__ = _MetaPacket
```

_Python 3_

``` python
class Packet(object, metaclass=_MetaPacket):
```

Using `six`, we can provide compatibility to both Python 2 and 3.
_Python 2 & 3_

``` python
with_metaclass(_MetaPacket, object)
```

However the problem is we introduce additional dependency to our project. According to Kiran's suggestion, we can avoid using `six` by adding two files named `dpkt2.py` and `dpkt3.py`, respectively providing support for Python 2 and 3.

Therefore we have two choices, selecting the related version during setup time or importing the related version at running time.

If we select the related version during setup time, we'll install the correct version of `dpkt` module when the user install the library. For instance, if the user run `python3 setup.py`, then we'll load `dpkt3.py`.

If we import the related version at running time, for instance, we'll import `dpkt3.py` if the `sys.version_info` is greater or equal to 3.

Thus which one do you think is better to provide both Python 2 and 3 support for metaclass?

items.title: Pick a docstrings style for the project
items.body:
dpkt needs docstrings. This might be a dependency for #20. However, It looks like there are many different docstring conventions, apart from [PEP 0257](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0257/). We should pick one style and settle with it for dpkt. 
Any recommendations? 

Here are some I found online:
- [Google Python Style Guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/pyguide.html?showone=Comments#Comments) (looks like this can be interpreted by Sphinx)
- [numpy style](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/HOWTO_DOCUMENT.rst.txt#docstring-standard)
- others?

Every time we work on a issue, we can add docstrings to the module at the same time. Hope is that eventually we will have good coverage..
